images.copyright: Cheetah in Maasai Mara National Reserve, Narok, Kenya (© Andy Rouse/naturepl.com)
images.title: Sprint for survival
images.caption: International Cheetah Day
images.desc: High atop a termite mound in the Maasai Mara National Reserve—a protected savanna in southwestern Kenya—a cheetah scans the plains. Its sleek body can reach speeds of over 120 km/h, making it the fastest land mammal on Earth. Long legs and a flexible spine allow incredible acceleration, while its strong tail helps maintain balance during high-speed chases. Today is International Cheetah Day—an event that couldn't have arrived any quicker. With fewer than 7,100 individuals left in the wild, these are among Africa's most vulnerable big cats.

og.title: International Cheetah Day

images.copyright: Sandhill cranes at sunrise, Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge, New Mexico, United States (© Jack Dykinga/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Dawn of the cranes
images.caption: Sandhill cranes, Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge, United States
images.desc: Every December, as morning unfolds, a chorus of rattling calls fills the marshes of the Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge. This more than 230-square-kilometre sanctuary in central New Mexico, United States, prepares to stage one of nature's most stirring performances as sandhill cranes return from their seasonal journey. Soon, tens of thousands of snow geese and other migratory birds join the scene, filling the sky with movement and sound.

og.title: Sandhill cranes, Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge, United States
og.desc: Every December, as morning unfolds, a chorus of rattling calls fills the marshes of the Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge. This…

images.title: Winter at Whistler
images.caption: Whistler, British Columbia
images.desc: What's your winter personality: cosy wanderer or slope-chaser? Whistler, in British Columbia, lets you try both in the same day. This resort municipality sits about 125 kilometres north of Vancouver in the Coast Mountains, with two main ski peaks: Whistler and Blackcomb. These are linked by the PEAK 2 PEAK Gondola, famous for giving a suspended, panoramic valley view in just a few minutes of travel. The area gained fame when it co-hosted the 2010 Winter Olympics, and some of those venues are still open to the public today. The name 'Whistler' comes from the high-pitched call of the local hoary marmots that were once common around the slopes.

images.copyright: Natural arch carved in an iceberg, Antarctica (© Gabrielle/Adobe Stock)
images.title: Where ice holds its breath
images.caption: Antarctica Day
images.desc: Some photos capture nature's grand acts. Great photos reveal even more in a single frame: the delicate balance between immense power and fragile beauty that surrounds us on Earth. Today's image of a natural arch carved into an Antarctic iceberg does exactly that—a conversation starter about grandeur, vulnerability, our environment and its present and future.

og.title: Antarctica Day

images.copyright: Christmas market in Leipzig, Germany (© Krzysztof Baranowski/Getty Images)
images.title: Twinkle all the way
images.caption: Christmas market in Leipzig, Germany
images.desc: Do you know what people bought at Christmas markets 567 years ago? Not costly ornaments or fancy souvenirs but candles, spices, local goods, knitted items and toys. Leipzig's Christmas market began in 1458 and quickly became a favourite stop for merchants and locals alike. Today, with its cultural and culinary offerings spread across the historic old town and about 300 stalls, it is one of the largest Christmas markets in Germany. Imagine streets buzzing with the chatter of traders and children following the scent of 'Lebkuchen'—honey-sweetened cakes. This is where townsfolk gather to celebrate winter and catch up on news while sipping mulled wine. These markets have always symbolised more than shopping—they offer an escape from the everyday routine.

og.title: Christmas market in Leipzig, Germany
og.desc: Do you know what people bought at Christmas markets 567 years ago? Not costly ornaments or fancy souvenirs but candles, spices, local goods…

images.copyright: Red deer stag in De Hoge Veluwe National Park, Netherlands (© CreativeNature_nl/Getty Images)
images.title: Oh deer, it's cold!
images.caption: Red deer stag in De Hoge Veluwe National Park, Netherlands
images.desc: Picture 55 square kilometres of open land, wildlife on the move and a stag flaunting its crown of antlers. In 1909, husband and wife Anton Kröller and Helene Kröller-Müller began building a private estate in Gelderland, Netherlands—what we now know as De Hoge Veluwe National Park. Their vision? To merge art and nature. They brought it to life by placing artwork within the landscape, like 'Three Upright Motives' by English sculptor Henry Moore in the Pampelse Zand and the President Steyn stone bench by Belgian architect Henry van de Velde, among others.

images.copyright: Val Brandet, Brescia, Lombardy, Italy (© ClickAlps/Alamy)
images.title: Echoes in white
images.caption: Val Brandet, Brescia, Lombardy, Italy
images.desc: Some valleys ask to be explored; Val Brandet in Lombardy, Italy, invites you to slow down and listen. Tucked inside Adamello Park and part of the municipality of Corteno Golgi—named after Nobel Prize–winning physician Camillo Golgi—this valley balances science and scenery, memory and movement.

images.copyright: Eastbourne Pier, East Sussex, England (© Tolga_TEZCAN/Getty Images)
images.title: Standing the test of tide
images.caption: Eastbourne Pier, East Sussex, England
images.desc: When it comes to seaside icons, Eastbourne Pier doesn't just make waves—it has been riding them for over 150 years. Opened in 1870, this Victorian marvel in East Sussex has survived tempests, fires and even wars. Stretching gracefully into the English Channel, the pier started life as a docking point for steamers. Over time, it evolved into a place where you can stroll above the water, lose a few coins to an arcade machine and gain a few back in memories.
